spanishExample: ¿No ibas a hacer eso?
englishTranslation: You weren’t going to do that?
vocabIncluded: ibas: "were going", "you were going" (Ir, imperfect, 2nd person)
using Ir and "a" to put verbs in the future (e.g. "voy a ser")

spanishExample: ¿Tú no vas, o *you hope* que yo vaya?
englishTranslation: You aren’t going, or you hope I go?
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)

spanishExample: Ahora estamos yendo *there.*
englishTranslation: Right now we’re going there.

spanishExample: Ahora están en la casa.
englishTranslation: Right now they are at the house.

spanishExample: El chico y la chica lo iban a hacer.
englishTranslation: The boy and the girl were going to do it.
vocabIncluded: iban: "were going", "they were going" (Ir, imperfect, 3rd person plural)
using Ir and "a" to put verbs in the future (e.g. "voy a ser")

spanishExample: Ella no estaría aquí con ustedes.
englishTranslation: She wouldn’t be here with you(all).
vocabIncluded: estaría: "would be", "he/she/it would be" (Estar, conditional, 3rd person)
ustedes: plural "you" after a preposition (prep. pronoun)

spanishExample: Estamos en el lugar, pero ellos fueron a casa.
englishTranslation: We are at the place, but they went home.

spanishExample: Estamos siendo *different.*
englishTranslation: We’re being different.

spanishExample: Están en la casa con nosotros.
englishTranslation: They are at the house with us.

spanishExample: Estaríamos aquí para que ella vaya.
englishTranslation: We would be here so that she goes.
vocabIncluded: estaríamos: "would be", "we would be" (Estar, conditional, 1st person plural)

spanishExample: Estoy aquí por *the event.*
englishTranslation: I’m here because of the event.

spanishExample: Estuve muy *angry* ese día.
englishTranslation: I got very angry that day.

spanishExample: He estado aquí todo el tiempo, pero tú te fuiste.
englishTranslation: I have been here all the time, but you left.
vocabIncluded: he: "have", "I have" before a participle (Haber, present, 1st person)
irse: any use of Ir with a reflexive pronoun, changing the meaning to "leave"

spanishExample: Hemos hecho lo que ella nos había *asked.*
englishTranslation: We have done what she had asked us.
vocabIncluded: "lo que": "what" as a connector between phrases
había: "had", "he/she/it had" before a participle (Haber, imperfect, 3rd person)
hemos: "have", "we have" before a participle (Haber, present, 1st person plural)
nos: "us" as an indirect object ("to us", "for us")

spanishExample: *I hope* que todos vayan cuando estemos en casa.
englishTranslation: I hope everyone goes when we are at home.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)

spanishExample: *I think* que ella ha ido a *where* él fue.
englishTranslation: I think she has gone to where he went.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
ha: "has", "he/she/it has" before a participle (Haber, present, 3rd person)

spanishExample: *I think* que estarías aquí si *you had* eso.
englishTranslation: I think you would be here if you had that.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
estarías: "would be", "you would be" (Estar, conditional, 2nd person)

spanishExample: *I want* que esté *where* yo había estado.
englishTranslation: I want her to be where I had been.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
había: "had", "I had" before a participle (Haber, imperfect, 1st person)

spanishExample: *I want* que vayas como yo voy.
englishTranslation: I want you to go like I go.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)

spanishExample: Íbamos a ir al lugar contigo.
englishTranslation: We were going to go to the place with you.
vocabIncluded: al: "to the" before a masculine noun
using Ir and "a" to put verbs in the future (e.g. "voy a ser")
íbamos: "were going", "we were going" (Ir, imperfect, 1st person plural)

spanishExample: La amiga de la chica no ha hecho nada más.
englishTranslation: The girl’s friend(f) hasn’t done anything else.
vocabIncluded: ha: "has", "he/she/it has" before a participle (Haber, present, 3rd person)

spanishExample: La amiga de mi mamá estaba aquí para que *we could work.*
englishTranslation: My mom’s friend(f) was here so that we could work.

spanishExample: Los *I have* para hacer eso.
englishTranslation: I have them(m) in order to do that.
vocabIncluded: para: "in order", "in order to" before an infinitive

spanishExample: Los iba a hacer.
englishTranslation: I was going to do them(m).
vocabIncluded: iba: "was going", "I was going" (Ir, imperfect, 1st person)
using Ir and "a" to put verbs in the future (e.g. "voy a ser")

spanishExample: No fui *because* lo habías *ruined.*
englishTranslation: I didn’t go because you had ruined it.
vocabIncluded: habías: "had", "you had" before a participle (Haber, imperfect, 2nd person)

spanishExample: No fuimos, *so* no lo *we saw.*
englishTranslation: We didn’t go, so we didn’t see it(m).

spanishExample: No iré por nada en *the world.*
englishTranslation: I won’t go because of anything in the world.
vocabIncluded: iré: "will go", "I will go" (Ir, future, 1st person)

spanishExample: No soy lo que él era.
englishTranslation: I am not what he was.
vocabIncluded: "lo que": "what" as a connector between phrases

spanishExample: No *you can* ir *where* él va.
englishTranslation: You can’t go where he is going.

spanishExample: Para ese día, ella les habrá *given* eso.
englishTranslation: By that day, she will have given them that.
vocabIncluded: "para": "by" a moment in time, as in "by then"
habrá: "will have", "he/she/it will have" before a participle (Haber, future, 3rd person)
les: "them" as an indirect object ("to them", "for them")

spanishExample: Por favor, quiero ir con su amigo.
englishTranslation: Please, I want to go with her friend(m).

spanishExample: Sí *I know* que eso está mal.
englishTranslation: I DO know that that is wrong.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
sí: adverb meaning "indeed" or otherwise providing positive emphasis

spanishExample: Sí, es un buen amigo.
englishTranslation: Yes, he’s a good friend.

spanishExample: Su amigo irá para *to help.*
englishTranslation: Her friend(m) will go in order to help.
vocabIncluded: irá: "will go", "he/she/it will go" (Ir, future, 3rd person)
para: "in order", "in order to" before an infinitive

spanishExample: *They hope* que yo sea bueno.
englishTranslation: They hope I’m good(m).
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)

spanishExample: Usted iba a estar ahí.
englishTranslation: You(formal) were going to be there.
vocabIncluded: ahí: adverb meaning "there", especially when close to the speaker or listener
iba: "was going", "he/she/it was going" (Ir, imperfect, 3rd person)
using Ir and "a" to put verbs in the future (e.g. "voy a ser")
usted: "you", formal subject pronoun, taking 3rd-person treatment

spanishExample: Ustedes *know* que *the movie* es por *a different director.*
englishTranslation: You all know that the movie is by a different director.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
ustedes: "you" plural, subject pronoun (3rd-person plural treatment)

spanishExample: Va de la casa al lugar.
englishTranslation: He goes from the house to the place.
vocabIncluded: al: "to the" before a masculine noun

spanishExample: Vamos si él va.
englishTranslation: We’re going if he goes.

spanishExample: Van con alguien que no *they know.*
englishTranslation: They are going with someone that they don’t know.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)

spanishExample: Voy a estar en casa cuando vayamos.
englishTranslation: I’m going to be at home when we go.

spanishExample: Ya habían estado ahí.
englishTranslation: They had already been there.
vocabIncluded: ahí: adverb meaning "there", especially when close to the speaker or listener
habían: "had", "they had" before a participle (Haber, imperfect, 3rd person plural)
ya: adverb meaning "anymore", "already", and a variety of other time-related things

spanishExample: Ya lo habíamos hecho.
englishTranslation: We had already done it.
vocabIncluded: habíamos: "had", "we had" before a participle (Haber, imperfect, 1st person plural)
ya: adverb meaning "anymore", "already", and a variety of other time-related things
